JONATHAN MASTERSON: My
name is Jonathan Masterson.

I'm creative producer for
Silent Partner Studios.

My role is a blend of
creativity, production,
and technology.

I try to blend
the three aspects.

At Silent Partner,
our work ranges

from broadcast,
AR, esports, award

shows to live music
and pop artists.

It's a combination
of all these elements
that we tend to explore.

My background is
music production.

I was a recording engineer and
worked in major French studios
for 10 years.

And I switched to a
technical direction
in theaters and stages.

That's where I spent the
next seven years, maybe,
of my career.

All of a sudden, I discovered
real-time environment,

creative coding, 3D content
creation tools and fell in love
with that industry.

So I had to reinvent
myself and start learning
something completely new.

Coming from the stage
and the theater,

live performance has always
been the core of my inspiration.

So obviously,
real-time environments
allow a lot of flexibility.

We can create queues that
can be triggered at any time

and follow the
artist's performance,

instead of having the artist
follow a pre-rendered contract
or background.

One project that
really stands out

is the musical
adaptation of La Haine.

The set design was
very technical,

with the turntable and the
treadmill as the actor walked
the whole movie.

And we needed a
lot of flexibility

to adapt the camera moves
that are iconic of this movie
to the stage.

We couldn't have done
it without Unreal Engine

because we needed to adapt
the background to the actor's
movement or musical cues.

So it was very important for us
to be able to react on the spot
to the director's decision.

In our studio, we have people
with very different backgrounds.

Some come from VFX, motion
design, architecture.

And some come from game
engine and pure development.

So we love to have
very different brains
and artistic visions.

Obviously, we're looking for
people that can do beautiful

scene lighting, amazing shaders,
and beautiful environments
and 3D modeling.
That's kind of a given.

But we also want people that
are able to optimize the scene

and to make something run at 30
FPS on the volume, for instance.

It's very important
for us to have

people that have a nice vision,
that can do beautiful things,

but also that
understand performances.

The most important skill
for us is the ability

to reinvent yourself and to
have a constant curiosity
to learn all the new tools.

This industry evolves
so fast that we
need to learn all the time.

And we shouldn't be afraid
of just throwing away

a workflow that
worked for ages when
there's a new workflow coming.

My tip for students
and new grads that

are looking to
master Unreal Engine,

first is be curious and to
love art, love live events.
Go and see shows.
Go to museums.
Read books.

That's the main source of
inspiration of our artists.

We're always out of the box,
always out of the computers.

And that's what makes us
always reinventing ourselves.
